CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 10;Pecuniary damage - award;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Anatoly Kovler;Elisabet Fura;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in the town of GPE in LOC . He is a journalist .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant published an article in issue no . CARDINAL\CARDINAL of the PERSON newspaper . The article appeared under the headline ‘ Tortured suspects confessed to the theft they had not ORG ( “ PERSON пыткой подозреваемые сознались в краже , которой не совершали ” ) . It concerned an investigation into the theft of property of a private company . The company director had identified CARDINAL of his former employees as prime suspects . PERSON , CARDINAL of those CARDINAL , had gone to the LOC police station of his own will to clear himself of suspicion . The story then switched to a first - person narrative by PERSON , which was preceded by the author ’s statement , in bold and in italics : “ I switched on the dictaphone recording of S[. ] ’s story ” .

CARDINAL . Mr S. said that he had been detained TIME at LOC police station . TIME he had been brought to an office where CARDINAL police officers had been present ; PERSON had been among them . PERSON continued as follows :

“ It was a DATE . They [ the police officers ] planned to go to a wedding party after lunch ; they reeked of fresh alcohol , it looked like they had already been drinking . They discussed how to torture me - using a crow - bar or otherwise ? They tied me to a chair , my legs fastened to the chair legs and my arms cuffed behind the chair back . At first they punched me in the chest with their fists , it hurt . I was in a state of shock . Then , a sudden , stunning blow to the neck ... I could not see who delivered the blow and with what object . Someone said : ‘ What now ? The crow - bar?’ G[. ] says : ‘ Well , but do not stain my NORP . And he took all the magazines off the table . CARDINAL of them , who squinted a bit , took out a tool that looked like a tyre lever . I do not know how they wanted to torture me . G[. ] says : ‘ No , let ’s try a gas mask first’ . They put a gas mask on me ... I could not breathe in or out , I felt faint and my head shook ... ” ( emphasis added , see below ) .

CARDINAL . The article further continued to relate PERSON story as told by him . After a while Mr S. had signalled his readiness to confess . He had been taken to the office next door , where a young man in civilian clothes had written down his statements . Thereafter , PERSON had been locked in the basement cell of the police station .

Switching back to author ’s speech , the applicant introduced PERSON , a friend of PERSON , who had gone to the police station to confirm Mr S. ’s alibi . With the words “ Let us give [ M. ] the floor ” , the story continued as narrated by PERSON :
“ At LOC police station they took me into office no . CARDINAL on the second floor . The interview was conducted by the investigator G[. ] , a tall athletic man with red hair .
– Where is the snatch ?
– What snatch ?
– ... Your friends have already confessed . You are the ‘ weak link’ . You are an ‘ MDP’ – a morally degraded person ...
He began beating me . Every word was followed by a blow ...

– Where is the loot ? You will tell me ! I am a paratrooper . I used to crush people like you and I will do the same to you ! Ever heard about disappearances ? You will be CARDINAL of them if you do not give back the loot !
... I heard that if the police accidentally break the leg or arm [ of a detainee ] , operational officers have to finish the victim off and secretly bury him so as to hide the traces of torture ...

G[. ] says : ‘ Stop talking like a parrot . Counsel , counsel ... Counsel will be at trial , but now you are under pre - trial investigation . Take him to the cell where the faggots are ! They are hungry , let them explain to him what he is.’ But he did not hit me . Just banged his fist on the table . As if they started to realise that they had made a mistake and were at a loss what to do next . ” ( emphasis added , see below ) .

CARDINAL . In the conclusion the applicant quoted from a medical report which noted multiple bruises and abrasions on Mr S. ’s body . He criticised the passive attitude of supervising prosecutors who had refused to initiate a criminal case against PERSON and the other police officers , and noted that the ORG refusals were being appealed against to a court . The real perpetrator had later been identified and convicted of the theft .

CARDINAL . The senior operational officer of LOC police station , PERSON sued the applicant and the newspaper ’s founder for defamation before ORG of GPE . Considering that the extracts in bold above were untrue and damaging to his honour , dignity and professional reputation , he sought compensation for non - pecuniary damage and legal costs . He denied that he had ever used violence against Mr S. or Mr M.

CARDINAL . The applicant maintained that the contested extracts had been a verbatim reproduction of the personal stories of PERSON and PERSON and represented their value judgments on these events . He had acted in good faith and verified that neither Mr S. nor Mr PERSON had a reason to slander or denigrate PERSON The extracts either did not refer to PERSON personally ( such as “ they reeked of fresh alcohol ... ” ) or did not contain any information damaging to his reputation ( such as the statement about him being a paratrooper ) . The applicant produced in evidence a dictaphone recording of his conversation with PERSON , when PERSON had been also present . He also relied on the medical report noting PERSON injuries , on the records of the confessions made by PERSON and Mr M. at the LOC police station , and on their complaints about ill - treatment lodged with the prosecutor ’s office .

CARDINAL . ORG took oral evidence from Mr S. and Mr PERSON confirmed the accuracy of the story as reproduced in the article . Responding to questions from both parties , he testified that police officers but not PERSON had reeked of alcohol , that he had been tied to a chair , that PERSON had indeed warned them against staining his table , that PERSON had not used violence against him but had been “ merely present ” . PERSON also confirmed his story as narrated in the article .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE granted PERSON action in part . It noted firstly that the applicant and the newspaper could not claim an exemption from liability for defamation on the ground that they had merely reproduced statements made by others , because no such exemption was provided for in the Mass Media Act . Accordingly , they were required to prove the accuracy of the contested statements . However , in the ORG view , neither the medical reports noting injuries on Mr M. ’s and Mr S. ’s bodies , nor their interview records , nor their oral testimony could be considered relevant evidence or proof of the truthfulness of the allegations that PERSON had tortured them or made intimidating remarks .
Furthermore ,

“ ... it follows from S[. ] ’s oral testimony that G[. ] had not been in an inebriated state during the interview , that he had not suggested using a gas mask , that he had not resorted to physical violence and that S[. ] had not told [ the applicant ] about that . A comparison of the dictaphone recording of S[. ] ’s story with the narrative in the article leads to the conclusion that the events were retold in the article in a different chronological order and that the author creatively rewrote PERSON ’s statements , increasing the emotional intensity and emphasising G[. ] ’s leading part in the use of violence towards the detainees . ”

CARDINAL . ORG , however , accepted that the statement about Mr PERSON ’s being a paratrooper was not damaging to his reputation and that Mr M. ’s statement about the victims being “ finished off ” by the police did not concern PERSON personally . The remaining extracts were found damaging to his reputation and liable to rectification .
CARDINAL . ORG awarded Mr MONEY ( MONEY ) and legal costs against the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , on an appeal by the applicant and the newspaper , upheld the judgment .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Civil Code provides that an individual may apply to a court with a request for the rectification of “ statements ” ( “ сведения ” ) that are damaging to his or her honour , dignity or professional reputation if the person who disseminated such statements does not prove their truthfulness . The aggrieved person may also claim compensation for losses and non - pecuniary damage sustained as a result of the dissemination of such statements .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that compensation for non - pecuniary damage is payable irrespective of the tortfeasor ’s fault if damages were sustained through dissemination of information damaging dignity , honour or reputation .
